titleInfo.title: Assessing the Effectiveness of a Training Program for Voice Quality Ratings

name.namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.abstract: Purpose: The purpose of this study was to assess the effect of a training program on the accuracy and reliability of student perception in rating voice quality features of breathiness and roughness. It was hypothesized that students who completed a voice quality features training module as a mastery task would more accurately and reliably rate the breathiness and roughness in a set of voice samples. Methods: Voice samples used originated from the Voice Foundation's Perceptual Voice Qualities Database. All voices in the database were rated for severity of voice qualities of breathiness and roughness by trained listeners. As a result of problems in administering the training program, the post-test was not completed and the pre-test data was not analyzed. Training modules had a set file of 12 anchor voices with features containing varying degrees of severity for breathiness and roughness, in addition to normal breathiness and roughness. Participants could listen to anchor voices an unlimited number of times. Results: Within-subjects effects were analyzed using a 3x3 repeated measures ANOVA. Greenhouse-Geisser estimate was used to correct the degrees of freedom to more accurately analyze the data. Repeated measure ANOVA revealed no significant effects for task, module, or the interaction between task and module. Within-subjects contrast analysis revealed a significant quadratic interaction between task and module. Participants exhibited a trend for improved ratings for individual breathy and rough characteristics, however, there is wide group variability in the accuracy of ratings and time taken to complete the training modules. Discussion: Varying patterns across individuals may indicate differing levels of motivation. Future research can further evaluate the impact of extrinsic and intrinsic motivation on skill acquisition and professional competence when completing a training module to improve voice perception judgment based on interest, level and degree of voice experience, and self-efficacy following pre and post-tests.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
anchor file, Reliability, training module, Voice quality perception
Richard J. Morris, Professor Directing Thesis; Yunjung Kim, Committee Member; Kaitlin L. Lansford, Committee Member.
